title: 10-Day Rwanda & Uganda Gorilla Safari
tagline: Two Countries. Two Gorilla Habitats. One Unforgettable Journey.
description: Begin in the clean, green hills of Kigali — one of Africa's most livable capitals — and end ten days later at a lakeside camp in Uganda, carrying memories that will reshape how you see the natural world. This cross-border safari is built around a single, transformative experience: coming face to face with mountain gorillas. You'll trek them in Uganda's Bwindi Impenetrable Forest, with optional gorilla tracking in Rwanda's misty Volcanoes National Park — home of the legendary Dian Fossey. In between, you'll cross an ancient border on foot, spend a full day with the extraordinary Bakiga people, search for tree-climbing lions in Ishasha, glide down the Kazinga Channel as hippos yawn at your boat, trek chimpanzees through a jungle gorge, and farewell Uganda with a papyrus-canoe encounter with the prehistoric shoebill stork. Few trips pack this much into ten days. Fewer still do it across two countries.

itinerary.title: Arrival in Kigali
itinerary.description: Welcome to Rwanda — one of Africa's great success stories. Your guide meets you at Kigali International Airport and transfers you to your comfortable guesthouse in the heart of the city. Kigali is compact, safe, and surprisingly vibrant: take an evening stroll through the hilly streets, sample some Rwandan coffee, and let the warmth of East Africa settle over you. Tomorrow the gorilla highlands await. Tonight, rest — you've earned the adventure ahead.

Transfer to accommodation in Kigali
Optional evening walk through Kigali's hilltop neighbourhoods

highlights: First taste of Rwanda's remarkable capital
Rest and orientation

itinerary.title: Kigali to Volcanoes National Park
itinerary.description: The drive northwest from Kigali into the Virunga Massif is one of the most beautiful in Africa. Terraced hillsides rise steeply on either side, tea plantations catch the morning light, and the volcanic cones of the Virunga mountains slowly climb above the cloud line. Volcanoes National Park is one of the few places on Earth where you can track mountain gorillas, and Dian Fossey spent years here studying them — laying the foundation for their survival. Tonight, settle into your guesthouse on the forest edge and listen to the sounds of the mountain night.
activities: Scenic morning drive from Kigali through the Virunga highlands
Stop at viewpoints over the volcanic mountain range

highlights: Dramatic Virunga volcanic landscape

itinerary.title: Cultural Experience & Border Crossing into Uganda
itinerary.description: A rich day of cultural adventures before you cross into Uganda. The ebyowacu community near the park offers an extraordinary window into traditional Rwandan highland life — a meaningful way to understand the people who live alongside the gorillas. Optional extras today include tracking the endangered golden monkey (a playful primate unique to the Virunga mountains), hiking to the tomb of the legendary primatologist Dian Fossey, or climbing one of the volcanoes for breathtaking panoramic views. In the afternoon, you cross the border on foot through one of the great landscapes of East Africa, arriving at Travellers Rest Camp in Kisoro — just a stone's throw from Uganda's gorilla forests. The gorillas sleep nearby. Tomorrow you find them.

itinerary.title: Gorilla Trekking in Bwindi Impenetrable Forest
itinerary.description: The day that defines the trip. After an early breakfast you assemble at park headquarters for your ranger briefing — which gorilla family you'll visit, what to expect, the rules of engagement. Then you push into Bwindi: a cathedral of ancient trees, strangling vines, moss-covered branches, and a thousand shades of green. The gorillas may be 30 minutes away or three hours — the rangers know their territory intimately, and every step deepens the anticipation. When you find them, time stops. A silverback shifts in the undergrowth. An infant watches you from its mother's shoulder. A teenager charges playfully, then retreats. You have one unforgettable hour, and it will stay with you for life.
activities: Early breakfast and briefing at Bwindi park headquarters
2–6 hour gorilla trek through the rainforest
One full hour with a habituated gorilla family

itinerary.title: Bakiga Cultural Homestay
itinerary.description: The Bakiga people inhabit the fertile highlands of southwestern Uganda and are among the most welcoming communities in East Africa. Today you are not a tourist — you are a guest. Spend the day with a Bakiga family: help with the farming, try your hand at traditional basket weaving or pottery, share a meal cooked the way it has been cooked for generations. The drumbeats and dances that have marked Bakiga celebrations for centuries will fill the evening. This is not a performance — it is a genuine invitation into a living culture, and it is consistently one of the moments guests remember longest.

itinerary.title: Transfer to Ishasha — Tree-Climbing Lions
itinerary.description: Today you trade the cool highland mist for the warm savannah air of southern Queen Elizabeth National Park. The drive through the forest is spectacular — the terrain shifts dramatically from terraced highlands to open bushland as you descend towards the Ishasha sector. Ishasha is famous for something you will find almost nowhere else in Africa: lions that climb trees. It sounds improbable, but there they are — sprawled in the branches of giant fig trees, tails dangling, regarding you with magnificent indifference. Your afternoon game drive is your first chance to spot them.

Afternoon game drive in Ishasha sector of QENP

itinerary.title: Northern QENP — Game Drive & Kazinga Channel
itinerary.description: The morning game drive continues the search for lions, then carries you north through Queen Elizabeth National Park towards the Kazinga Channel — a 40km natural waterway connecting Lake George and Lake Edward. In the afternoon you board a boat and glide into one of Uganda's finest wildlife experiences. Hippos groan and jostle at the waterline. Crocodiles eye your boat from the mud. Buffalo wade belly-deep to drink. And the birdlife is extraordinary: fish eagles, bee-eaters, kingfishers, pelicans, and herons line the banks in an avian pageant that has no equal in East Africa.

itinerary.title: Chimpanzee Trekking — Kyambura Gorge
itinerary.description: This morning you descend into the Kyambura Gorge — a dramatic rift valley canyon that cuts through the savannah like a secret jungle, its steep walls cloaked in dense rainforest. Somewhere in the canopy above the gorge floor, a community of chimpanzees are starting their day. Finding them is the challenge, and your ranger-guide knows every trail. When you do find them, the noise announces them first: the hooting, screaming, and branch-crashing of primates very much at home. Watch them feed, play, and swing through the trees with casual athleticism. An evening game drive on the savannah above rounds out an extraordinary day.

itinerary.title: Morning Game Drive & Return to Entebbe
itinerary.description: One last early morning drive — the savannah gold and cool at first light, lions perhaps still in the trees, hippos retreating to their daytime pools. Then it's time to head north, back towards Entebbe. The drive is long but passes through beautiful countryside, and your guide will find stops worth making along the way. You'll arrive in Entebbe in the late afternoon, checking in near the airport for a comfortable final night before tomorrow's farewell encounter with Uganda's most eccentric bird.

itinerary.title: Mabamba Swamp & Departure
itinerary.description: Your final morning in Uganda is saved for one of its most charming encounters: the shoebill stork. At Mabamba swamp on the northern shore of Lake Victoria, you board a papyrus canoe and paddle quietly into the reed beds where this extraordinary, prehistoric-looking bird stands stock-still in the shallows, waiting for fish with the patience of a creature from another age. It's a wonderfully surreal farewell to Uganda. Afterwards, a celebratory farewell lunch — perhaps Lake Victoria tilapia — and then the airport for your onward flight. We hope you're already planning your return.

faqs.question: Do I need visas for both Rwanda and Uganda?
faqs.answer: Yes — you will need entry visas for both countries. Rwanda visas are available on arrival or via the Rwanda e-visa portal. Uganda visas cost $50 and must be applied for online before travel. Both countries participate in the East Africa Tourist Visa scheme, which allows a single $100 visa covering Rwanda, Uganda, and Kenya — often the most cost-effective option. We advise on the best option when you book.

faqs.question: Is the Rwanda gorilla permit included?
faqs.answer: The Uganda gorilla trekking permit ($800 per person) is included in the base price. Rwanda gorilla tracking on Day 3 is optional and costs $1,500 per person — we recommend it if your budget allows, as tracking gorillas in two different countries on the same trip is a rare and extraordinary experience. Please let us know at booking so we can secure the Rwanda permit in advance.

faqs.question: What is the Bakiga homestay experience like?
faqs.answer: The Bakiga homestay is a genuine cultural immersion, not a staged performance. You stay with a real Bakiga family in the Kabale highlands, eat the same food they eat (full board), participate in daily farming and craft activities, and spend the evening around the fire with traditional music and storytelling. Accommodation is simple but clean and comfortable. This day is consistently one of the most talked-about moments of the entire trip.

faqs.question: How physically demanding is the gorilla trek?
faqs.answer: A moderate level of fitness is recommended. Treks can last 2–6 hours through hilly, sometimes muddy forest terrain. The pace is always set by the slowest member of the group, and porters are available at the trailhead to carry your bag and offer a steadying hand. We have seen guests of all ages and fitness levels complete the trek successfully. The adrenaline of finding the gorillas makes you forget any tiredness immediately.

faqs.question: What is the shoebill stork and why is it special?
faqs.answer: The shoebill is one of the world's most unusual and sought-after birds — a massive, slate-grey wading bird with a prehistoric-looking hooked bill the size of a wellington boot. It stands completely motionless for long periods in the reed beds, then strikes at fish with explosive speed. Mabamba Swamp on Lake Victoria is one of the most reliable places in Africa to find one. Seeing a shoebill on your final morning is the perfect, surreal farewell to Uganda.

faqs.question: Can this safari be extended?
faqs.answer: Absolutely. Popular additions include an extra night at Lake Bunyonyi for swimming and relaxation, chimpanzee trekking at Kibale Forest, a white rhino tracking visit at Ziwa Sanctuary, or Murchison Falls National Park for game drives and the Victoria Nile boat cruise. We can also extend into Kenya or Tanzania. Contact us and we'll design the perfect custom itinerary.
